--- title: "Hands-on Exercise 3" subtitle: "Spatial Point Patterns Analysis" author: "Kai Feng" date: "August 30, 2024" date-modified: "last-modified" execute: eval: true echo: true freeze: true --- ## **1.0 1st Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods** Spatial Point Pattern Analysis is a method used to study how points are spread out over an area. These points can represent: - Events like crimes, traffic accidents, or disease outbreaks. - Locations of businesses such as coffee shops, fast food places, or facilities like childcare centers and eldercare services. In this exercise, we'll use a tool called `spatstat` to analyze the distribution of childcare centers in Singapore. **Questions we want to answer are:** 1. **Are childcare centers in Singapore spread out randomly, or is there a pattern?** 2. **If they’re not randomly distributed, where are the areas with the highest concentration of childcare centers?** ## **2.0 Setup** ### **2.1 Installing R-Packages** - [**sf**](https://r-spatial.github.io/sf/) for handling geospatial data - [**spatstat**](https://spatstat.org/) for point pattern analysis. In this exercise, it will be used to perform 1st- and 2nd-order spatial point patterns analysis and derive kernel density estimation (KDE) layer. **To study how points are distributed & to create a density map showing where points are concentrated** - [**raster**](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/raster/) deals with grid-based spatial data, like satellite img. In this exercise, we'll use it to convert images created by spatstat into a format that raster can work with. - [**maptools**](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/maptools/index.html) for manupulating geographic data. In this exercise, we mainly use it to convert *Spatial* objects -\> *ppp* format of **spatstat**. - [**tmap**](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/tmap/index.html) package ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(sf, raster, spatstat, tmap, tidyverse, devtools,sp) ``` ::: ### **2.2 Data Acquisition** 3 datasets will be used: - `CHILDCARE`, a point feature data providing both location and attribute information of childcare centres. It was downloaded from Data.gov.sg and is in geojson format. - `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL`, a polygon feature data providing information of URA 2014 Master Plan Planning Subzone boundary data. It is in ESRI shapefile format. This data set was also downloaded from Data.gov.sg. - `CostalOutline`, a polygon feature data showing the national boundary of Singapore. It is provided by SLA and is in ESRI shapefile format. ### **2.3 Importing Geospatial Data into R** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} childcare_sf <- st_read("data/child-care-services-geojson.geojson") %>% st_transform(crs=3414) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `child-care-services-geojson' from data source `C:\Users\ngkng\Desktop\School\Geo -Local\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex03\data\child-care-services-geojson.geojson' using driver `GeoJSON' Simple feature collection with 1545 features and 2 fields Geometry type: POINT Dimension: XYZ Bounding box: xmin: 103.6824 ymin: 1.248403 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134 z_range: zmin: 0 zmax: 0 Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sg_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data", layer="CostalOutline") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `CostalOutline' from data source `C:\Users\ngkng\Desktop\School\Geo -Local\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex03\data' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' Simple feature collection with 60 features and 4 fields Geometry type: POLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 2663.926 ymin: 16357.98 xmax: 56047.79 ymax: 50244.03 Projected CRS: SVY21 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sf <- st_read(dsn="data", layer="MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source `C:\Users\ngkng\Desktop\School\Geo -Local\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex03\data' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33 Projected CRS: SVY21 ``` ::: ::: ### **2.4 Assigning Standard Coordinate Systems** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sg_sf <- st_transform(sg_sf, crs=3414) mpsz_sf <- st_transform(mpsz_sf, crs=3414) ``` ::: ### **2.5 Data Preparation and Wrangling** ##### 2.5.1 Convert simple feature data frame to sp's Spatial\* class ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} childcare <- as_Spatial(childcare_sf) mpsz <- as_Spatial(mpsz_sf) sg <- as_Spatial(sg_sf) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} childcare ``` ::: 2.5.2 Convert Spatial\* class into generic sp format \* **spatstat** requires the analytical data in **ppp** object form. **(Need convert to Spatial Object first -\> ppp object)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} childcare_sp <- as(childcare, "SpatialPoints") sg_sp <- as(sg, "SpatialPolygons") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} childcare_sp ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` class : SpatialPoints features : 1545 extent : 11203.01, 45404.24, 25667.6, 49300.88 (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) crs : +proj=tmerc +lat_0=1.36666666666667 +lon_0=103.833333333333 +k=1 +x_0=28001.642 +towgs84=0,0,0,0,0,0,0 +units=m +no_defs ``` ::: ::: \* **Diff between Spatial\* classes & generic sp object:** Spatial\* classes are specialized versions of spatial objects tailored for different types of spatial data, while the generic sp object provides a base class with fundamental spatial features that can be extended by the more specific Spatial\* classes. ##### 2.5.3 Convert generic sp format into spatstat's ppp format ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} childcare_ppp <- as.ppp(st_coordinates(childcare_sf), st_bbox(childcare_sf)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: data contain duplicated points ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} childcare_ppp ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Marked planar point pattern: 1545 points marks are numeric, of storage type The statistical methodology used for spatial point patterns processes is based largely on the assumption that process are simple, that is, that the points cannot be coincident.** ## **3.0 Handling {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 128 ``` ::: ::: ### **View locations of these duplicated point events:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tmap_mode('view') tm_shape(childcare) + tm_dots(alpha=0.4, size=0.05) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tmap_mode('plot') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` tmap mode set to plotting ``` ::: ::: ### **3.3 3 ways to overcome duplicate points** - Delete the duplicate -\> but, this will result in some useful point events be lost - jittering -\> this will add a small perturbation to the duplicate points so that they do not occupy the exact same space. - make each point 'unique' + attach the duplicates of the points to the patterns as marks, as attributes of the points. Then you would need analytical techniques that take into account these marks. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} childcare_ppp_jit <- rjitter(childcare_ppp, retry=TRUE, nsim=1, drop=TRUE) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} any(duplicated(childcare_ppp_jit)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] FALSE ``` ::: ::: ## **4.0 Creating owin object** When analysing spatial point patterns, it is a good practice to confine the analysis with a geographical area like Singapore boundary. In **spatstat**, an object called ***owin*** is specially designed to represent this polygonal region. Analysis** ### **5.1 Kernel Density Estimation (KDE)** ##### 5.1.1 Computing kernel density estimation using automatic bandwidth selection method - [*bw.diggle()*](https://rdrr.io/cran/spatstat/man/bw.diggle.html) automatic bandwidth selection method. Other recommended methods are [*bw.CvL()*](https://rdrr.io/cran/spatstat/man/bw.CvL.html), [*bw.scott()*](https://rdrr.io/cran/spatstat/man/bw.scott.html) or [*bw.ppl()*](https://rdrr.io/cran/spatstat/man/bw.ppl.html). - The smoothing kernel used is *gaussian*, which is the default. Other smoothing methods are: “epanechnikov”, “quartic” or “disc”. - The intensity estimate is corrected for edge effect bias by using method described by Jones (1993) and Diggle (2010, equation 18.9). The default is *FALSE*. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} kde_childcareSG_bw <- density(childcareSG_ppp, sigma=bw.diggle, edge=TRUE, kernel="gaussian") plot(kde_childcareSG_bw) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: \* Density values is 0 to 0.000035 (too small to understand) -\> because default unit of measurement of svy21 is in meter **\[so it is computed in no. of points/sq meter\]** **To retrieve bandwidth used to compute the kde layer:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bw <- bw.diggle(childcareSG_ppp) bw ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` sigma 298.4095 ``` ::: ::: ##### 5.1.2 Convert unit of measurement from meter -\> km ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} childcareSG_ppp.km <- rescale.ppp(childcareSG_ppp, 1000, "km") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} kde_childcareSG.bw <- density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma=bw.diggle, edge=TRUE, kernel="gaussian") plot(kde_childcareSG.bw) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ##### 5.1.3 **Different automatic badwidth methods** - bw.CvL() - bw.scott() - *bw.ppl()* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bw.CvL(childcareSG_ppp.km) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` sigma 4.543278 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bw.scott(childcareSG_ppp.km) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` sigma.x sigma.y 2.224898 1.450966 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bw.ppl(childcareSG_ppp.km) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` sigma 0.3897114 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bw.diggle(childcareSG_ppp.km) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` sigma 0.2984095 ``` ::: ::: Baddeley et. (2016) suggested the use of the *bw.ppl()* algorithm because in ther experience it tends to produce the more appropriate values when the pattern consists predominantly of tight clusters. But they also insist that if the purpose of once study is to detect a single tight cluster in the midst of random noise then the *bw.diggle()* method seems to work best. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} kde_childcareSG.ppl <- density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma=bw.ppl, edge=TRUE, kernel="gaussian") par(mfrow=c(1,2)) plot(kde_childcareSG.bw, main = "bw.diggle") plot(kde_childcareSG.ppl, main = "bw.ppl") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-37-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ##### 5.1.4 **Different kernel methods** Default in *density.ppp()* is *gaussian. \[Choose from Epanechnikov, Quartic and Dics\]* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} par(mfrow=c(2,2)) plot(density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma=bw.ppl, edge=TRUE, kernel="gaussian"), main="Gaussian") plot(density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma=bw.ppl, edge=TRUE, kernel="epanechnikov"), main="Epanechnikov") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, : Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} plot(density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma=bw.ppl, edge=TRUE, kernel="quartic"), main="Quartic") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, : Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} plot(density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma=bw.ppl, edge=TRUE, kernel="disc"), main="Disc") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in density.ppp(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, : Bandwidth selection will be based on Gaussian kernel ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ##### 5.1.4 **Fixed and Adaptive KDE** ###### 5.1.4.1 **Computing KDE by using fixed bandwidth** Next, you will compute a KDE layer by defining a bandwidth of 600 meter. Notice that in the code chunk below, the sigma value used is 0.6. This is because the unit of measurement of ***childcareSG_ppp.km*** object is in kilometer, hence the 600m is 0.6km. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} kde_childcareSG_600 <- density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma=0.6, edge=TRUE, kernel="gaussian") plot(kde_childcareSG_600) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-39-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ###### 5.1.4.2 **Computing KDE by using adaptive bandwidth** very sensitive to highly skew distribution of spatial point patterns over geographical units for example urban versus rural. One way to overcome this problem is by using adaptive bandwidth instead. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} kde_childcareSG_adaptive <- adaptive.density(childcareSG_ppp.km, method="kernel") plot(kde_childcareSG_adaptive) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-40-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Fixed VS Adaptive Kernel density estimation:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} par(mfrow=c(1,2)) plot(kde_childcareSG.bw, main = "Fixed bandwidth") plot(kde_childcareSG_adaptive, main = "Adaptive bandwidth") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-41-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ###### 5.1.4.3 **Converting KDE output into grid object** The result is the same, we just convert it so that it is suitable for mapping purposes ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw <- as(kde_childcareSG.bw, "SpatialGridDataFrame") spplot(gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw) ``` ::: Confirmatory Spatial Point Patterns Analysis by using Nearest Neighbour statistics.** In this section, we will perform the Clark-Evans test of aggregation for a spatial point pattern by using [*clarkevans.test()*](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/spatstat/versions/1.63-3/topics/clarkevans.test) of **statspat**. The test hypotheses are: Ho = The distribution of childcare services are randomly distributed. H1= The distribution of childcare services are not randomly distributed. The 95% confident interval will be used. ##### 5.2.1 **Testing spatial point patterns using Clark and Evans Test** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} clarkevans.test(childcareSG_ppp, correction="none", clipregion="sg_owin", alternative=c("clustered"), nsim=99) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Clark-Evans test No edge correction Z-test data: childcareSG_ppp R = 0.55631, p-value < 2.2e-16 alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1) ``` ::: ::: ##### 5.2.2 **Clark and Evans Test: Choa Chu Kang planning area** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} clarkevans.test(childcare_ck_ppp, correction="none", clipregion=NULL, alternative=c("two.sided"), nsim=999) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Clark-Evans test No edge correction Z-test data: childcare_ck_ppp R = 0.92168, p-value = 0.2419 alternative hypothesis: two-sided ``` ::: ::: ##### 5.2.3 **Clark and Evans Test: Tampines planning area** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} clarkevans.test(childcare_tm_ppp, correction="none", clipregion=NULL, alternative=c("two.sided"), nsim=999) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Clark-Evans test No edge correction Z-test data: childcare_tm_ppp R = 0.77871, p-value = 6.503e-05 alternative hypothesis: two-sided ``` ::: ::: ## **6.0 Drawing a Spatial Point Map** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tm_shape(mpsz_sf) + tm_polygons() + tm_shape(childcare_sf) + tm_dots() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-60-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: \* All the layers on the map fit together properly because they use the same coordinate system. This means they all refer to the same geographical area, which is crucial for accurate mapping and analysis. ### OR -\> Pin Map ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tmap_mode('view') tm_shape(childcare_sf) + tm_dots() ``` ::: \* Using interactive mode in **tmap** -\> can zoom in & out. Click on points to see more info \* Can choose from different background map styles. **Default = ESRI.WorldGrayCanvas**. (Choose from ESRI.WorldGrayCanvas, OpenStreetMap, and ESRI.WorldTopoMap) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tmap_mode('plot') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` tmap mode set to plotting ``` ::: ::: \* **Switch back to "plot". Because each interactive mode consume a connection. Avoid \>10 in 1 RMarkdown doc when publish on Netlify** ## **7.0 Second-order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis** #### 7.1 **Analysing Spatial Point Process Using G-Function** The G function measures the distribution of the distances from an arbitrary event to its nearest event. Compute G-function estimation by using [*Gest()*](https://rdrr.io/cran/spatstat/man/Gest.html) of **spatstat** package. Perform monta carlo simulation test using [*envelope()*](https://rdrr.io/cran/spatstat/man/envelope.html) of **spatstat** package. #### 7.1.1 **Choa Chu Kang planning area** #### Computing G-function estimation ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} G_CK = Gest(childcare_ck_ppp, correction = "border") plot(G_CK, xlim=c(0,500)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-63-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: #### Performing Complete Spatial Randomness Test To confirm the observed spatial patterns above, a hypothesis test will be conducted. The hypothesis and test are as follows: Ho = The distribution of childcare services at Choa Chu Kang are randomly distributed. H1= The distribution of childcare services at Choa Chu Kang are not randomly distributed. The null hypothesis will be rejected if p-value is smaller than alpha value of 0.001.
